title: Acid-Base Titration
description: Determine the concentration of an unknown acid solution using a standard base solution. Master the art of precise measurements and endpoint detection.

stepDetails.title: Prepare Equipment
stepDetails.description: Set up the burette in the stand and rinse with distilled water, then with the NaOH solution. Fill the burette with 0.1M NaOH solution.

stepDetails.title: Prepare Sample
stepDetails.description: Using a pipette, transfer exactly 25.0mL of the unknown HCl solution into a clean conical flask.

stepDetails.title: Add Indicator
stepDetails.description: Add 2-3 drops of phenolphthalein indicator to the acid solution in the conical flask. Place on white tile for better endpoint visibility.

stepDetails.title: Initial Titration
stepDetails.description: Record the initial burette reading. Begin titrating by adding NaOH solution slowly while swirling the flask continuously.

stepDetails.title: Identify Endpoint
stepDetails.description: Continue adding NaOH drop by drop near the endpoint. The endpoint is reached when the solution turns permanently pale pink.

stepDetails.title: Calculate Concentration
stepDetails.description: Record the final burette reading and calculate the volume of NaOH used. Use the formula to determine the concentration of the HCl solution.

safetyInfo: Handle all chemicals with care. NaOH is caustic and can cause burns. HCl is corrosive. Always wear safety goggles and handle glassware carefully. Work in a well-ventilated area.

title: Chemical Equilibrium
description: Investigate Le Chatelier's principle by observing how changes in concentration, temperature, and pressure affect chemical equilibrium. Study the cobalt(II) chloride equilibrium system.

stepDetails.title: Prepare Solutions
stepDetails.description: 1. Take a test tube and add a small amount of cobalt chloride crystals. 2. Add distilled water slowly and stir until it dissolves. 3. You will see a pink solution because of the hydrated [Co(H₂O)₆]²⁺ complex.

stepDetails.title: Add Concentrated HCl
stepDetails.description: Slowly add drops of concentrated HCl to the cobalt solution. Observe the color change from pink to blue as the equilibrium shifts.

stepDetails.title: Dilute with Water
stepDetails.description: Add distilled water to the blue solution. Observe the color change back to pink as the equilibrium shifts in the reverse direction.

stepDetails.title: Temperature Effect - Heating
stepDetails.description: Heat the pink solution in a water bath. Observe how increased temperature affects the equilibrium position and color.

stepDetails.title: Temperature Effect - Cooling
stepDetails.description: Cool the heated solution in an ice bath. Observe how decreased temperature shifts the equilibrium back.

stepDetails.title: Record Observations
stepDetails.description: Document all color changes and relate them to Le Chatelier's principle. Calculate equilibrium constants where applicable.

safetyInfo: Concentrated HCl is highly corrosive. Cobalt compounds are toxic if ingested. Always wear safety goggles, gloves, and work in a well-ventilated area. Handle hot and cold solutions with appropriate equipment.

title: Chemical Equilibrium 1
description: To study the shift of equilibrium between ferric ions and thiocyanate ions by increasing the concentration of either ions. Observe the formation and dissociation of the blood-red FeSCN²⁺ complex.

stepDetails.title: Prepare Stock Solutions
stepDetails.description: Prepare 0.1M FeCl₃ solution and 0.1M KSCN solution. Label each solution clearly for identification.

stepDetails.title: Establish Initial Equilibrium
stepDetails.description: In a test tube, mix equal volumes (5mL each) of FeCl₃ and KSCN solutions. Observe the formation of blood-red FeSCN²⁺ complex. This represents the equilibrium: Fe³⁺ + SCN⁻ ⇌ FeSCN²⁺

stepDetails.title: Divide Into Four Tubes
stepDetails.description: Divide the equilibrium solution into 4 equal portions in separate test tubes. Label them as Control, +Fe³⁺, +SCN⁻, and +OH⁻.

stepDetails.title: Add Excess Fe³⁺ Ions
stepDetails.description: To the +Fe³⁺ tube, add 2-3 drops of concentrated FeCl₃ solution. Observe the color change and intensity. Record how the equilibrium shifts according to Le Chatelier's principle.

stepDetails.title: Add Excess SCN⁻ Ions
stepDetails.description: To the +SCN⁻ tube, add 2-3 drops of concentrated KSCN solution. Observe the color change and compare with the previous tube. Note the direction of equilibrium shift.

stepDetails.title: Remove Fe³⁺ with OH⁻
stepDetails.description: To the +OH⁻ tube, add 2-3 drops of NaOH solution. The OH⁻ ions will precipitate Fe³⁺ as Fe(OH)₃, removing it from equilibrium. Observe the color change and document results.

safetyInfo: Iron(III) chloride is corrosive and can stain skin and clothing. Potassium thiocyanate is toxic if ingested. Sodium hydroxide is caustic. Always wear safety goggles and gloves. Handle all chemicals in a well-ventilated area.

title: Chemical Equilibrium 2
description: To study the shift in equilibrium between [Co(H₂O)₆]²⁺ and Cl⁻ by changing the concentration of either ions. Observe dramatic color changes between pink hydrated and blue chloride complexes.

stepDetails.title: Prepare Cobalt Solution
stepDetails.description: Dissolve a small amount of cobalt(II) chloride hexahydrate (CoCl₂·6H₂O) in distilled water. Observe the pink color of the hydrated [Co(H₂O)₆]²⁺ complex.

stepDetails.title: Establish Equilibrium System
stepDetails.description: The equilibrium system is: [Co(H₂O)₆]²⁺ + 4Cl⁻ ⇌ [CoCl₄]²⁻ + 6H₂O. The pink form represents the hydrated complex, while blue represents the chloride complex.

stepDetails.title: Add Concentrated HCl
stepDetails.description: Slowly add concentrated HCl (source of Cl⁻ ions) to the pink solution. Observe the color change to blue as equilibrium shifts toward [CoCl₄]²⁻ formation.

stepDetails.title: Dilute with Water
stepDetails.description: Add distilled water to the blue solution to increase H₂O concentration. Observe the shift back to pink as equilibrium favors [Co(H₂O)₆]²⁺ formation.

stepDetails.title: Temperature Effect - Heating
stepDetails.description: Heat the equilibrium mixture in a water bath to 60°C. The forward reaction is endothermic, so heating favors blue [CoCl���]²⁻ formation.

stepDetails.title: Temperature Effect - Cooling
stepDetails.description: Cool the heated solution in an ice bath to 0°C. Cooling favors the exothermic reverse reaction, shifting equilibrium toward pink [Co(H₂O)₆]²⁺.

stepDetails.title: Analyze and Document
stepDetails.description: Record all observations and color changes. Explain each shift using Le Chatelier's principle. Relate concentration and temperature effects to equilibrium position.

safetyInfo: Concentrated HCl is highly corrosive and produces toxic vapors. Cobalt compounds are suspected carcinogens and toxic if ingested. Always use in a fume hood or well-ventilated area. Wear safety goggles, gloves, and appropriate protective clothing.
